example.name: more or less clear
example.text: Yet he is also firmly bound by his hard-line rhetoric and promises he made to anti-abortion activists during his long pursuit of the White House.
example.arg: by his hard-line rhetoric and promises he made to anti-abortion activists during his long pursuit of the White House

example.name: nasty trace chains
example.text: The fundamental rule of contract law applied to both cases was that courts will not enforce agreements to which [the parties]-1 did not intend *trace*-1 to be bound *[*T]*.

example.name: some kind of understood agreement?
example.text: In the Pennzoil/Texaco litigation, the courts found [Pennzoil and Getty Oil]-3 intended *trace* to be bound *trace*-3; in Arcadian Phosphates they found there was no intention to be bound.

example.name: raising verb!
example.note: trace points to 'they', but leave that aside.

example.name: more than likely
example.text: In our system of advocacy, the trial lawyer is duty bound *trace* to present the best case he possibly can.''
example.arg: *trace* to present the best case he possibly can

example.name: glory bound
example.text: [It]-1 is rumored *trace* to be bound *trace*-1 for a new model in the luxury Acura line in the U.S., but Honda officials wouldn't comment.
example.arg: for a new model in the luxury Acura line in the U.S.

example.text: For most people, [dishes such as these]-1 are forever bound *-1 up with the spirit of New Year.
